The Third Education Development Project (the Project) will build on the 
achievements  of  the  Education  Sector  Development  Program  (ESDP) 
and Second Education Development Project (SEDP) and will assist the 
Government  in  improving  the  quality  and  relevance  of  primary, 
secondary,  and  vocational  education.  The  Project  has 
three 
components:  (i)  developing  a  national  curriculum  framework  and 
aligned  education  standards,  (ii)  improving  teaching  and  learning 
environments  in  primary  and  secondary  schools,  and  (iii)  promoting 
demand-driven vocational education for the youth.  
 
Key  issues  in  the  current  Mongolian  education  system  are  (i)  poor 
quality  and  relevance  of  the  current  curriculum  for  primary  and 
secondary  education,  (ii)  inadequate  teaching  qualifications  and  skills, 
(iii)  lack  of  consistent  education  standards,  (iv)  weak  learning  and 
teaching  environments  in  schools,  and  (v)  supply-driven  irrelevant 
vocational education for youth. The Government has decided to extend 
the  education  system  from  the  current  10-year  system  to  a  12-year 
system  in  2008,  which  will  align  Mongolia’s  education  system  with 
international standards. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will assist 
the Government in the implementation of this policy, which will require 
comprehensive  reform  of  the  curriculum  framework,  establishing  new 
education standards, streamlining the current teacher in-service training 
system, and developing a national teacher accreditation system.  
 
The  limited  capacity  and  poor  condition  of  school  facilities—which 
continue  to  deteriorate—are  major  constraints  to  increasing  enrolment 
and retention, and improving the quality of education services. This has 
been particularly acute in rural areas where budget funds for preventive 
maintenance  and  technical  resources  for  rehabilitation  are  scarce. 
Building  construction  and  technology  are  inefficient  in  terms  of  use  of 
materials, structural capacity, and energy performance.

The  Ministry  of  Education,  Culture  and  Science  (MECS)  is  the  sole 
public  sector  provider  of  vocational  and  technical  education  (VTE)  for 
the  youth.  Currently,  vocational  education  programs  are  based  on  the 
former  Soviet  system,  which  is  neither  responsive  to  labor  market 
demands  nor  cost-effective.  Graduates  have  difficulty  finding  jobs 
because they lack employable skills. School facilities have deteriorated,

system  will  need  to  be  adjusted  to  the  new  national  curriculum 
framework. 
 
ADB’s  assistance  to  the  education  sector  in  Mongolia  has  evolved 
since  the  early  1990s  to  support  the  Government  in  strengthening  the 
education  system  step-by-step.  ESDP  was  approved  in  1996  and 
included  a  program  loan  to  support  fundamental  policy  reforms  in  the 
organization,  management,  staffing,  and  financing  of  the  education 
sector;  and  a  project  loan  to  support  initial  investments.  SEDP  was 
approved in 2002 and builds on the initial reform framework established 
by  ESDP,  with  a  focus  on  school  and  kindergarten  rehabilitation, 
provision  of  learning  materials,  and  limited  support  in  curriculum 
development  and  teacher  training.  The  Project  focuses  on  two  major 
features which have not been addressed by previous interventions: (i) a 
comprehensive  curriculum  reform,  in  support  of  the  Government’s 
decision  to  extend  the  schooling  period  by  2  years;  and  (ii)  reforming 
the  current  VTE  system,  which  is  a  development  priority  of  the 
Government to enhance employment and income-earning opportunities 
and  promote  economic  growth.  The  Project  contributes

The  impact  of  the  Project  will  be  improved  employability  and  income-
earning  opportunities  of  graduates  from  secondary  and  vocational 
education.  The  outcome  of  the  Project  will  be  enhanced  and  more 
equitable access to—and improved quality and relevance of—primary, 
secondary, and vocational education. 
 
The  total  project  cost  is  estimated  at  $16.38  million  equivalent.  The 
foreign  exchange  cost  is  estimated  at  $3.83  million  (24%  of  the  total 
cost)  and  the  local  currency  cost  is  estimated  at  $12.55  million 
equivalent (76% of the total cost).

The project steering committee (PSC) established under SEDP will be 
reorganized  and  will  consist  of  eight  members—two  representatives 
from  MECS,  one  from  Ministry  of  Labor  and  Social  Welfare,  and  two 
from  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Economy;  and  one  each 
from 
nongovernment organizations, industry, and development partners. The 
chairman will be appointed by the minister of education and will be the 
project  director.  The  PSC  will  provide  strategic  guidance,  monitor 
implementation  of  the  Project,  and  ensure  donor  coordination.  The 
project  director  will  coordinate  overall  implementation  of  project 
activities.  The  Project  will  be  implemented  through  the  current  project 
implementation unit (PIU) established under ESDP, staffed by a project 
manager and five additional staff, who will be responsible for the overall 
implementation of activities. MECS will provide office space for the PIU. 
The  PIU  will  report  to  the  project  director  and  provide  quarterly  result-
based progress reports to the PSC, MECS management, and ADB.  
 
Goods  and  services  financed  by  ADB  will  be  procured  in  accordance 
with  its  Procurement  Guidelines.  Procurement  of  civil  works  will  be 
carried  out  through  national  competitive  bidding.  Procurement  of 
equipment will be performed through international competitive bidding, 
and national competitive bidding satisfactory to ADB, and shopping.

A  total  of  8  person-months  of  international  and  265  person-months  of 
domestic consulting services will be contracted under loan funds. This 
will  include  experts  in  the  field  of  policy  development,  curriculum  and 
standards  development, 
training,  and  civil  engineers 
specialized  in  school  rehabilitation.  Consultants  will  be  recruited  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  In 
addition,  Germany  [GTZ]  is  expected  to  provide  grant  assistance  for 
40 person-months of international consultants and UNICEF is expected 
to  finance  6  person-months  of  international  and  4  person-months  of 
national consultants. 
 
Direct  beneficiaries  of  the  Project  will  include  all  students  enrolled  in 
primary and secondary schools. Nationwide, about 560,000 students—
including  about  201,000  students  from  poor  families—will  benefit  from 
improved  curriculum,  well-defined  education  standards,  and  enhanced 
assessment  systems.  About  31,000  students  and  1,200  teachers  will 
benefit from improved school and dormitory facilities in 45 schools to be 
rehabilitated under the Project. In addition, about 23,000 students and 
900 teachers of 30 model schools will benefit from upgraded teaching 
facilities.  Rehabilitation  works  will  contribute  to  reduce  the  cost  of 
utilities and operation and maintenance (O&M). About 21,400 teachers 
throughout  the  country  will  benefit  from  in-service  teacher  training 
programs.  
  
About  21,900  students  of  vocational  education  institutions  will  benefit 
from  reform  of  the  VTE  system  and  a  new  demand-driven  curriculum, 
which will improve their employment and income-earning opportunities 
after  graduation.  Student  and  teachers  of  six  key  VTE  institutions  will 
benefit  from  rehabilitated  facilities  and  modern  training  equipment. 
Industries and services will benefit from improvements in relevance and 
quality  of  VTE.  Graduates  of  VTE  institutions  entering  the  labor  force 
will  possess  knowledge  and  skills  in  line  with  industry  requirements, 
contribute to higher labor productivity, and increase economic growth. 
 
Successful implementation of the Project rests on the assumption that 
the  Government  will  (i)  maintain  the  high level  of  budget allocation  for 
the education sector; (ii) be committed to improve donor coordination to 
strengthen the effectiveness and efficiency of the delivery of education 
services;  (iii)  maintain  its  commitment  to  carry  out  education  reforms, 
including  national  curriculum  reform;  (iv)  provide  adequate  budget  to 
provide in-service training for all teachers employed by the system; and 
(v)  reform  and  rationalize  the  current  VTE  system.  To  achieve  its 
impact,  the  Project  assumes  that  further  steady  economic  growth  will 
create new job opportunities. 
 
The  managerial  and  technical  capacity  of  MECS  is  limited  and  might 
affect the smooth implementation of the extension of the school system 
to  a  12-year  system  and  the  introduction  of  the  new  curriculum 
framework nationwide. The  risks  will  be mitigated through training and

capacity  building  under  the  Project.  The  policy  impact  of  introducing 
new  education  standards  and  uniform  assessments  will  be  significant. 
Risks  include  resistance  from  teachers  and  school  directors  to  accept 
changes  to  implement  the  new  curriculum  framework  and  introduce 
uniform  examinations.  The  risks  will  be  mitigated  by  adopting  a 
participatory  approach  to  project  implementation,  actively  involving 
school  directors,  teachers,  and  communities.  Financial  risks  involve 
potential  difficulties  in  the  provision  of  incremental  recurrent  costs  for 
O&M  of  rehabilitated  schools.  To  mitigate  the  risk,  ADB  will  work 
closely  with  the  Government  to  ensure  that  adequate  resources  are 
allocated  for  the  education  sector,  incremental  recurrent  costs  are 
assigned for O&M, and appropriate assurances are included. 
 
ADB  will  provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  strengthen  MECS’ 
technical  and  management  capacity  in  strategic  planning  and  policy 
analysis,  and  enable  the  ministry  to  set  up  a  sector  wide  approach  in 
the education sector. The total cost of the TA is estimated at $210,000 
equivalent,  of  which  $55,000  is  the  foreign  exchange  cost  and 
$155,000 equivalent the local currency cost. ADB will provide $150,000 
on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will 
finance the balance through provision of workshop facilities, counterpart 
staff, office space, and furniture for TA administration.

2. 
In 2002, the Government requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide TA to

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

Socioeconomic Context 

1. 
 
3. 
After  14  years  of  economic  transition,  Mongolia  stands  out  as  a  good  performer  among 
transition  economies.  Profound  economic  reform  has  led  to  the  successful  implementation  of  the 
pillars  of  a  market  economy  and,  at  present,  substantive  macroeconomic  stabilization  has  been 
achieved. However, gross domestic product (GDP) per capita ($602 in 2004) has not yet reached 
pre-transition  levels  and  poverty  has  emerged  as  an  unwelcome  side  effect  of  the  transition. 
Poverty spread on a large scale in the 1990s as a consequence of the structural transformation of 
the economy. Following the collapse of the socialist institutions, a range of services deteriorated, 
including  health  care,  education,  transportation,  water  supply,  and  sanitation.  Poverty  remains 
persistent  in  both  rural  and  urban  Mongolia  and  36%  of  the  population  live  below  the  national 
poverty line ($0.75 a day). Continued growth is helping to lift living standards but the benefits are 
not  distributed  equally  among  the  population,  as  revealed  by  income  inequality  and  unchanged 
poverty incidence. Rural poverty is significantly higher than urban poverty, with Western Mongolia 
standing out as the most seriously affected region. Sectoral composition of GDP has changed, with 
industry  and  services  expanding  fast  while  agriculture  has  declined.  This  has  led  to  a  significant 
migration  flow  from  the  countryside  to  the  major  urban  centers,  which  has  caused  major 
imbalances  in  educational  service  provision.  A  total  of  57.4%  of  the  population  currently  lives  in 
urban centers.

Mongolia has a relatively young, economically active population. Of the total population of 
about  2.5  million,  38%  are  below  the  age  of  16,  and  55%  are  of  working  age.  The  sharp  fall  in

population’s growth rate declined from 2.7% in 1989 to 0.8% in 2004. 
 
High  unemployment  (14.2%)  and  underemployment  caused  by  a  mismatch  between

available skills and labor market needs is one of the major causes of poverty. The service sector is 
the  main  source  of  employment  in  Mongolia,  followed  by  agriculture  and  industry.  However,  the 
pattern  is  completely  different  in  urban  and  rural  areas.  While  services  account  for  75%  of  the 
employed in urban centers, they employ only 5% of the rural labor force, which is mainly engaged 
in livestock and farming activities. The lack of relevant knowledge and skills among poor migrants 
restricts their earning opportunities to intermittent low-wage employment in the informal sector and 
is  a  major  cause  of  poverty  among  this  group.  The  recent  Household  Income  and  Expenditure 
Survey  and  Living  Standards  Measurement  Survey5  found  that  the  poor  have  lower  education 
attainments  than  the  nonpoor  in  general;  and  lack  the  managerial,  professional,  or  technological 
skills required in burgeoning industries. The divide is particularly evident in urban areas where only 
14% of the poor possess skills in demand, compared with 38% of the nonpoor.  
 
6. 
Mongolia’s  experience  suggests  that  economic  growth  does  not  translate  into  poverty 
reduction  immediately,  given  the  narrow  base  of  the  economy  and  its  vulnerability  to  external 
shocks. Hence, specific interventions are required to combat poverty. Education is perceived as an 
important vehicle to reduce poverty, upgrade human development, and generate job opportunities. 
Improving  the  quality  and  relevance  of  education—both  in  urban  and  rural  areas—is  essential  to 
strengthen  the  country’s  human  capital,  widen  the  range  of  opportunities  for  employment 
generation, and promote competitiveness and private sector development.

Education Sector 

 
Education  was  one  of  Mongolia’s  main  achievements  in  the  socialist  era.  School  and

from  remote  nomadic  families—to  obtain  a  basic  education.  Results  were  impressive.  The  gross 
enrolment  rate  (GER)  in  primary  and  secondary  education  reached  99%  by  1990.  This  was 
accompanied by high literacy rates which, even in 2004, stood at 97% of the population aged over 
15.  With  the  termination  of  financial  and  technical  support  from  the  Soviet  Union  in  1991,  the 
quality of and access to education services in Mongolia deteriorated. State education expenditures 
were  massively  reduced.  Without  finance  for  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  and  essential 
repairs,  school  facilities  deteriorated  and  many  were  forced  to  close.  Availability  of  learning 
materials  dwindled  and  teachers’  real  salaries  eroded  distinctly.  By  1996,  the  GER  had  fallen  to 
82% and dropout rates6 had increased. A description of the education sector is in Appendix 2.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Key Issues and Challenges 

14. 
National  Curriculum  Framework  and  Revised  Education  Standards.  The  planned 
introduction of a new 12-year education system will need to be supported by curriculum reform and 
the  development  of  agreed  education  standards  for  each  subject  and  grade  level.  At  present,  a 
consistent broad curriculum frame linked to educational standards is not in place. The extension of 
the schooling period has not been reflected in recent curriculum revisions. The current education 
curriculum  is  overloaded  with  subjects  and  content  requirements,  with  insufficient  emphasis  on 
modern learning methodologies, and echoes learning arrangements of the socialist era, which are 
no longer consistent with the need for greater flexibility in subject selection and a student-centered 
teaching environment. MECS has started the process of revising education standards and a set of 
new standards has been published. However, the new education standards have not yet taken into 
account  the  need  to  modernize  the  curriculum  framework;  and  teachers,  parents,  and  textbook 
authors find the standards too complex and difficult to translate into clear student competences. At 
present, student examinations have little transparency due to lack of clear standards. Exams  are 
not  prepared  according  to  uniform  national  standards  and  are  not  comparable  between  schools, 
which makes it difficult to monitor quality.  
 
15. 
Teachers’  Qualifications.  The  main  constraints  on  improving  educational  quality  are  the 
lack  of  a  (i)  comprehensive  teacher  in-service  training  system,  and  (ii)  national  teacher 
accreditation system. Currently, there is no agreed national teacher accreditation system in place. 
Students  graduate  from  38  universities  and  colleges  with  different  levels  of  education.  Training 
programs  at  these  universities  and  colleges  do  not  follow  agreed  national  standards.  School and 
aimag (province) authorities are in charge of teacher recruitment and assessment. However, due 
to  the  lack  of  national  agreed  professional  standards  and  teacher  accreditation  schemes,  the 
knowledge and competence of new teachers vary from school to school.  
 
The  teaching  techniques  and  subject  knowledge  of  many  teachers  are  inadequate  and 
16. 
outdated  and  need  to  be  upgraded,  particularly  in  rural  areas.  The  shortage  of  qualified  English 
and vocational teachers is largely due to the inability of the education sector to compete with the 
private sector in employing personnel with these skills. Emphasis needs to be placed on improving 
teachers’  working  conditions  and  upgrading  their  qualifications.  Currently,  in-service  teacher 
training  is  carried  out  by  22  Education  and  Culture  Departments  (ECDs)  at  aimag  level,  some 
universities and colleges, and donor supported projects. However, training programs do not follow 
national standards, are not coordinated, and do not include all teachers employed by the system. 
The new national curriculum frame and the extension of the schooling period by 2 years will place 
new demands on teacher’s skills and competencies. 
 

 

 17. 
Facilities.  A  major  constraint  on  increasing  enrollment  and  retention  and  improving  the 
quality  of  education  services  is  the  limited  capacity  of  school  facilities,  which  continues  to 
deteriorate  due  to  inadequate  maintenance  and  investment.  This  has  been  particularly  acute  in 
rural areas, where budget funds for O&M and resources for rehabilitation are scarce. Lack of safe 
water and sanitation pose significant hygiene and health risks, especially for students in dormitory 
facilities.  Building  construction  and  technology  of  schools,  which  have  not  yet  benefited  form 
rehabilitation  measures,  are  based  on  30-year  old  construction  standards  that  are  inefficient  in 
terms  of  use  of  materials,  structural  capacity,  and  energy  performance.  Insulations  are  poor  and 
urban  schools’  heating  systems  are  usually  linked  to  a  public  heating  distribution  system  without 
metering or control of consumption.  
 
18. 
Recent  large-scale  migration  from  rural  to  urban  areas—in  addition  to  being  one  of  the 
results of declining service provision in rural areas—has caused major imbalances in educational 
service provision and has greatly tested the capacity of schools in areas witnessing high population 
inflows.11  Schools  in  urban  centers  have  seen  demand  for  services  increase  substantially,  while 
some rural schools are now operating below capacity as a result of outflows from their catchment 
areas.  The  introduction  of  a  12-year  system  in  2008  will  cause  a  significant  increase  in  student 
numbers in the national education system, which will be an additional burden on schools’ capacity. 
The  increase  in  enrollments  and  lack  of  additional  school  space  will  force  about  one  third  of  all 
secondary schools to conduct classes in two or even three shifts. MECS has identified 200 out of 
710  schools  in  urgent  need  of  rehabilitation,  which  will  require  donor  assistance  due  to  national 
budget  constraints.  The  lack  of  adequate  teaching  aids  and  learning  materials  is  another  major 
constraint  on  applying  modern  teaching  methodologies.  In  rural  schools,  in  particular,  teaching 
equipment for science subjects and up-to-date computer equipment are lacking. Reliance on more 
traditional resources, such as chalkboard and textbooks, in pre-service and in-service training had 
led to teaching being dominated by traditional "chalk and talk" centered learning. 
 
19. 
Vocational and technical education has been one of most neglected areas of education 
in  Mongolia.  The  Government  enacted  legislation  to  encourage  the  private  sector  to  become 
involved in VTE and subsequently reduced its role in this subsector. However, only a few private 
training providers and companies are engaged in vocational education and are providing support. 
Currently,  there  is  a  serious  mismatch  between  skills  supply  and  labor  market  demand,  which 
impedes  further  economic  growth  and  leads  to  lack  of  sufficiently  skilled  labor.  The  economic 
consequences  of  these  deficiencies  are  unemployment,  lagging  competitiveness,  insufficient 
innovation,  and  low  productivity.  At  present,  MECS  is  the  sole  public  provider  of  VTE  for  youth. 
Training  programs  for  youth  offered  by  private  training  institutions  are  limited  to  few  sectors  in 
urban areas. Students from rural areas are disadvantaged in gaining access to private training and 
children from poor families are unable to afford training fees. A lack of employment opportunities 
and adequate private and public training provisions make it crucial to promote VTE as a means to 
provide employable skills and knowledge to students who do not advance to higher education.   
 
20.  Mongolia’s  VTE  system  is  in  need  of  comprehensive  reform.  The  current  VTE  program—
offering  a  combined  2.5-year  professional  and  general  education  based  on  the  former  Soviet

system  have  difficulty  competing  with  the  academic  performance  of  graduates  from  the  general 
secondary education stream, and do not find jobs easily after graduation without further on-the-job-
training due to their lack of employable skills. With the introduction of the 12-year school system,

Government Policy 

22. 
The Government’s Economic Growth Support and Poverty Reduction Strategy (EGSPRS), 
the  National  Action  Plan,  and  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs)  for  education,  together 
describe  the  Government’s  development  strategy  in  the  education  sector.  The  Project  will

as an integral part of its (i) economic growth strategy, aimed at steady, private sector-led growth;

improving the quality and accessibility of public services.

(ESS) (2000–2005) and the Education for All strategic plan. The major focus of the ESS has been 
on  improvements  in  (i)  access  to,  and  quality  and  relevance  of,  basic  education  services;  and 
(ii) development  of  qualified  and  competitive  human  resources,  contributing  to  raise  economic 
growth.  Building  on  the  achievements  and  lessons  learned  from  the  ESS  (2000–2005),  MECS  is 
currently developing a new Education Master Plan for 2006–2015 with assistance from ADB.

Project  Beneficiaries.  Direct  beneficiaries  of  the  establishment  of  a  new  curriculum 
framework and the modernization of the education system will be all students enrolled in primary 
and secondary schools. Nationwide, about 560,000 students will benefit from improved curriculum, 
well-defined education standards, and enhanced assessment systems. About 31,000 students and 
1,200  teachers  will  benefit  from  rehabilitated  school  and  dormitory  facilities  in  45  schools.  About 
23,000  students  and  900  teachers  of  30  model  schools  will  benefit  from  upgraded  teaching 
facilities. About 21,400 teachers throughout the country will benefit from in-service teacher training

the  VTE  system  and  a  new  demand-driven  curriculum,  which  will  improve  their  employment  and 
income-earning  opportunities  after  graduation.  Student  and  teachers  of  four  key  VTE  institutions

improvements  in  relevance  and  quality  of  VTE.  Graduates  of  VTE  institutions  entering  the  labor

Education  Master  Plan  for  2006–2015  is  being  developed  with  the  assistance  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). 
 
2. 
The formal education system in Mongolia consists of kindergarten and preschool (up to 
age 7), primary education (4 years), lower secondary education (4 years), and upper secondary 
education (2 years). From the 2005–2006 school year, the Government will extend the structure 
of school education from grades 1–10 (4+4+2) to grades 1–11 (5+4+2), with the expectation of 
having  a  12-year  system  (6+3+3)  in  2008.  Basic  education  (primary  and  lower  secondary 
education)  is  compulsory  and  funded  by  the  state.  In  2004–2005,  557,346  students  were 
enrolled  in  710 primary  and  secondary  schools  with  a  total  of  21,458  teachers.  In  addition, 
MECS  administers  43  higher  education  institutions  and  42  vocational  and  technical  education 
(VTE)  institutions.  VTE  institutions  consist  of  22  vocational  education  and  training  centers 
(VETCs)/vocational  training  and  production  centers  (VTPCs)  that  offer  a  2.5-year  combined 
professional  and  general  education  based  on  the  former  Soviet  system,  which  leads  to  a 
professional  certificate  and  a  secondary  education  certificate;  and  14  branch  schools  and 
6 technical colleges  that  provide  advanced  training  for  higher-level  skills  development,  leading 
to a professional diploma or bachelors degree. In 2004–2005, 21,911 students were enrolled in 
VETCs/VTPCs/branch schools. An assessment of the VTE system is provided in Appendix 7. 
 
3. 
Higher  education  has  experienced  the  most  rapid  enrollment  expansion  of  any  level  of 
education  in  Mongolia  over  the  past  4  years.  The  number  of  higher  education  institutions  has 
increased to 178 during the past 10 years, of which 135 are private. Enrollment in private higher 
education institutions has more than doubled over the past 4 years. It is estimated that 80% of 
secondary  school  graduates  continue  into  postsecondary  education.  In  1994,  the  Government 
began requiring public higher education institutions to begin charging tuition at levels sufficient 
to  cover  the  entire  cost  of  academic  staff  salaries,  thus  generating  a  large  reduction  in  the 
government higher education budget. 
 
4. 
The  strength  of  the  Mongolian  education  system  is  its  high  coverage  of  a  widely 
dispersed population. This is reflected in a gross enrollment rate of 98% among the school-age 
population and an adult literacy rate of 97%. Further, unlike most developing countries, girls are 
not  disadvantaged  in  the  educational  system.  In  fact,  60%  of  all  students  enrolled  in  higher 
education  in  Mongolia  are  females.  However,  greater  attention  needs  to  be  paid  to  address 
issues  related  to  dropout  rates.  Table  A2.1  reflects  a  decline  in  the  dropout  rate  across  the 
entire  Mongolian  education  system,  yet  there  are  continuing  concerns  about  the  accuracy  of 
official  statistics.  In  a  recent  study  of  school  dropouts  in  Mongolia,  numbers  of  out  of  school 
children provided by different agencies ranged from 11,953 (MECS) to 68,115 (National Human

5. 
Key issues in the current Mongolian education system are (i) poor quality and relevance 
of  the  current  curriculum  for  primary  and  secondary  education,  (ii)  inadequate  teaching 
qualifications  and  skills,  (iii)  weak  learning  and  teaching  environments  in  schools,  and 
(iv) supply-driven  irrelevant  vocational  education  for  youth.  Despite  progress  in  revising  the 
curriculum  and  syllabi,  the  basic  education  curriculum  remains  overloaded  with  subject  and 
content requirements, with insufficient emphasis on student-centered learning. The Government 
has  decided  to  extend  the  current  organizational  structure  of  school  education  from  a  10-year 
system to a 12-year system in 2008, which will require reform of the curriculum framework and 
development  of  new  education  standards  linked  to  the  curriculum.  At  present,  student 
examinations  have  little  transparency  due  to  lack  of  clear  standards.  Exams  are  not  prepared 
according to uniform national standards or comparable between schools, which makes it difficult 
to  monitor  quality.  Lack  of  a  comprehensive  teacher  in-service  training  system  and  a  uniform 
national teacher accreditation system are key constraints on improving the quality of education. 
Teachers  graduate  from  universities  and  colleges  with  different  levels  of  education.  Teaching 
techniques and subject knowledge of many teachers are inadequate and outdated and need to 
be  upgraded.  In  addition,  the  extension  of  the  schooling  period  by  2  years  will  place  new 
demands on teachers’ skills and competencies. 
 
6. 
A major constraint in increasing enrolment and retention and in improving the quality of 
education services is the limited capacity of school facilities, which continues to deteriorate. This 
has been particularly acute in rural areas, where budget funds for preventive maintenance and 
technical resources for rehabilitation are scarce. Building construction and technology are based 
on  30-year  old  construction  standards,  which  are  inefficient  in  terms  of  use  of  materials, 
structural capacity, and energy performance. 
 
Currently, the harmonization level of donor activities in the education sector is very low. 
7. 
Donor-funded projects are not linked to the overall policy framework and are managed largely 
on  an  individual  basis.  The  low  coordination  level  results  in  ineffective  and  inefficient  use  of 
scarce  resources  in  the  education  sector.  The  new  Education  Master  Plan  will  provide  the 
necessary  policy  for  improved  coordination,  effectiveness,  and  efficiency  in  the  sector.  Policy 
objectives  established  under  the  master  plan  will  need  to  be  prioritized  and  translated  into 
operational  implementation  strategies  and  annual  budget  plans.  However,  due  to  MECS 
capacity  limitations,  an  effective  planning  structure  is  not  in  place.  Strategic  planning,  policy 
analysis, and evaluative research need to be strengthened to enhance planning and budgeting.

was only incremental budget increase for the last 15 years, which is way below the international 
average level of expenditure. There was no allocation for capital expenditure since 2004.  
 
B. 
 
8. 
MLSW  is  the  main  provider  of  vocational  training  in  the  form  of  short-term  courses  to 
train  and  retrain  adults.  There  are  no  strict  entry  qualifications  for  taking  up  training  courses. 
Participants  include  unemployed  adults,  secondary  school  leavers,  soldiers,  and  adults  who 
need  retraining  or  skills  upgrading.  Short-term  training  is  carried  out  by  private  and 
nongovernment training providers. About 358 vocational training centers (VTCs) were registered 
with MLSW to cater to adult training. Courses are mostly designed to cater to the service sector, 
such  as  training  of  hairdressers,  cooks,  accounting  assistants,  cosmetologists,  waitresses, 
receptionists,  salesgirls,  sewers,  textile  workers,  electricians,  computer  operators,  welders, 
carpenters, bricklayers, and interior and exterior decorators. The training duration ranges from 
1 to 3 months. 
 
9. 
The total number of unemployed persons who benefited from training at VTCs reached 
20,000  for  various  occupations.  This  represents  a  small  portion  of  the  150,000  persons  who 
registered for training in 2004. However, courses offered are highly redundant and produce an 
oversupply of trained persons, particularly in the service sector.  
 
C.  
 
10. 
One  serious  issue  in  VTE  is  the  need  to  rehabilitate  and  modernize  facilities  and 
equipment.  Due  to  years  of  inadequate  maintenance  and  investment,  school  buildings  have 
seriously deteriorated (including heating, electricity, and water and sanitation systems). Old and 
inefficient  building  construction  and  heating  technology  generate  high  utility  costs.  The  lack  of 
appropriate  equipment,  adequate  teaching  aids,  and  learning  materials  constrains  applying 
modern  teaching  methodologies.  The  quality  of  hands-on  skills  training  is  seriously  hampered 
by outdated training equipment, and lack of consumables and tools.

11. 
There were 1,160 teachers and trainers employed in the 42 VTE institutions in 2004, of 
which about 63% are female. The teacher-student ratio was 1:19, which is considered an ideal 
size. About one third of teachers in service are general education teachers. Most of the teachers 
have  bachelors  degree  and  about  1–5  years’  experience,  which  is  indicatively  short.  The 
pedagogical and technical skills and knowledge of many teachers are outdated and need to be 
upgraded. There is a lack of pre-service and in-service teacher education programs for technical 
VTE  teachers.  The  delivery  of  training  is  conventional  and  classroom-based,  with  little 
opportunity to develop practical skills due to lack of up-to-date equipment and training supplies. 
There is an acute shortage of learning resources. Most of the textbooks and resource materials 
are  seriously  outdated,  with  no  systematic  library  management  system  in  place.  There  are  no 
multimedia  facilities  or  even  classroom  computers  available  to  apply  modern  teaching  and 
learning methods. 
 
12. 
Currently, there is no comprehensive recognized national system for skills standards in 
place. The quality of skills training depends on the quality of instruction, which is often adversely 
affected  by  the  lack  of  training  materials  and  equipment,  and  poor  teaching  environment  and 
outdated  knowledge  of  teachers.  VTE  institutions  set  their  own  examination,  without  formal 
external quality control or moderation. The industry is only involved occasionally. 
 
E.

Orientation 

 
13.  MECS’  VTE  system  is  suffering  from  weak  interaction  with  industry,  poor  coordination 
with  MLSW  and  other  training  providers,  and  lack  of  an  elaborate  labor  market  assessment 
strategy to design programs of economic and social relevance. VTE is largely supply-driven and 
not significantly refocused to reflect the emerging needs of the labor market. The current labor 
market information system is unable to provide up-to-date labor market data to guide the design 
and revision of training programs. The lack of information and resource sharing among MECS, 
industry,  and  other  training  providers  lowers  the  quality  and  relevance  of  training  programs. 
MECS needs to improve strategies to explore ways to involve industry participation.  
 
A  review  of  courses  offered  under  MECS  and  MLSW  will  be  necessary  to  clearly

delineate  and  calibrate  the  type  and  level  of  courses  offered  by  each  ministry  to  avoid 
duplication  of  resources  and  redundancy  of  programs.  Moreover,  there  is  a  need  to  cluster 
courses  into  major  occupational  groups  to  warrant  international  classification  of  training, 
facilitate  standard  setting  and  international  benchmarking,  and  for  economy  of  scale  in 
equipment provision and maintenance.  
 
15. 
The  present  curricula  have  not  been  seriously  updated  in  the  past  and  need  major 
redesigning  to  conform  to  the  new  national  curriculum  framework.  There  are  only  16  training 
standards,  which  were  developed  from  1998  to  date  for  sewers  and  tailors  of  soft  items;  food 
production,  cooks  and  bakers;  electric  and  gas  welders;  carpenters;  plumbers  and  welders; 
mechanics  and  drivers;  shoemakers;  farmers;  hairdressers  and  beauticians;  construction 
masonry workers; general vocation in mining, repair and maintenance of mining equipment and  
drivers  of  heavy  load  machinery.  These  training  standards  appear  too  basic  and  almost 
duplicate  the  short-term  courses  at VTCs.  There  is  a  need  to  recalibrate  these  standards  and 
introduce  new  ones  for  multiskilled  development  rather  than  simple  operation  work.  Some 
constraints are the lack of an elaborate labor market survey and tracer studies, as well as the 
capacity and resources to undertake curriculum revision.

Public-private  partnership  needs  to be  improved  substantially.  The  private  sector could

19. 
The  recurrent  budget  of  a  VTE  school  is  based  on  enrollment.  The  variable  cost  of

present  system  of  public  budgeting  has  no  provision  for  recognizing  performance  as  an 
incentive  for  excellence.  This  is  important  to  foster  the  quality  of,  and  competition  in,  VTE 
provision. Another major drawback of the VTE system is the lack of financial autonomy. There is 
a need to initiate fiscal policy reform to improve the present financing mechanisms.

The  quality  assurance  system  in  VTE  is  weak.  The  accreditation  system  for  higher 
education  institutions  and  vocational  and  technical  training  centers  was  embodied  in  the

was established in 1998 as the national accrediting body. To date, only two vocational training 
centers  have  been  accredited  out  of  42  VTE  institutions.  An  accreditation  system  should  be 
developed  with  industry  participation  and  closely  coordinated  with  the  Mongolian  National 
Council  for  Education  Accreditation  to  enhance  the  present  accreditation  system.  A  NVQ 
framework does not exist in Mongolia.

B.  Poverty Analysis  
Overall,  36%  of  the  total  population  lived  in  poverty.  In  2002,  poverty  incidence  was  higher  in  rural  areas 
(43%) than in urban areas (30%); lowest in Ulaanbaatar (about 27%), where half of the population resides; 
and  highest  (51%)  in  the  Western  Region.  The  recent  World  Bank  analysis  of  the  Living  Standards 
Measurement Survey 1998 & 2002 finds that the negative impact of poverty on a child’s dropout from school 
is significant at every level of schooling—even at primary level where completion rates are near universal—
and  it  has  the  largest  effect  on  upper  secondary  dropout.  Poverty  affects  children’s  educational  outcomes 
directly (out-of-pocket and opportunity costs) and indirectly (family/parental background). Educational quality, 
as measured by examination results, is significantly lower in rural areas, and poorer soums (districts) perform 
worse than richer soums; and the quality of teaching influences parental decisions on whether to keep their 
children in school or not. The Government’s flagship social assistance program, the Child Money Programme 
(CMP), has started providing MNT3,000 per child per month to poor households, provided that the child is 
and continues to be enrolled in school (from 1 July 2005).4  Early findings of the ADB-funded Participatory 
Poverty  Assessment  and  Monitoring  Project  indicate  that  the  MNT3,000  per  child  is  considered  to  an 
important source of income for very poor families, although the informal charges levied by many schools are 
too high for the poor, even with CMP support. However, it has been estimated that 49%5 of recipients in the 
CMP are from nonpoor families and 17% of eligible poor families are excluded.   
 
There  has  been  increased  migration  from  rural  areas  to  peri-urban  areas,  mainly  in  search  of  better 
education,  health,  and  other  services;  and  income-earning  opportunities.  This  inflow  of  population  has 
caused  overcrowding  and  high  absenteeism  in  urban  schools  (nearly  7%  of  8  year  olds  do  not  attend 
school).  High  migration  rates  can  be  associated  with  poor  student  performance  in  schools,  fees  for 
preschools  and  boarding  facilities  are  prohibitive  for  aimag  and  soum  households,  the  indirect  cost  of 
schooling  in  relation  to  household  per  capita  expenditure  increases  significantly  for  grades  9  and  10,  and 
poorer families are underrepresented in upper secondary education in both rural and urban areas. In effect, 
poverty  is  an  important  factor  in  determining  whether  a  child  is  enrolled  in  school  or  not.  Yet,  without 
unhampered access to quality education, opportunities for earning a reasonable income and rising above the 
poverty line are restricted; indeed, graduates of at least secondary education are significantly less likely to be 
poor.

with  presentation  of  gender  roles  and  issues;  (iv)  give  high  priority  to  matching  skills  and  educational 
achievements to employment opportunities through demand-driven vocational education; and (v) encourage
